# History of the United Kingdom during the First World War

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the effect of the war on civilian and military life in
the United Kingdom, 1914–18. For information on the engagements in which its
armed forces fought, see [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World
War").

See also: [Timeline of the United Kingdom home front during the First World
War](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_United_Kingdom_home_front_during_the_First_World_War
"Timeline of the United Kingdom home front during the First World War")

The [United Kingdom of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland") was one of the [Allied
Powers](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I") during the First
World War of 1914–1918, fighting against the [Central
Powers](/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers") (the [German
Empire](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire"),[1] the [Austro-Hungarian
Empire](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire "Austro-Hungarian Empire"),[2] the
[Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire")[3] and the [Kingdom of
Bulgaria](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bulgaria "Kingdom of Bulgaria")[4]). The state's
armed forces were reorganised—the war marked the founding of the [Royal Air
Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force"), for example—and increased in
size because of the introduction, in January 1916, of
[conscription](/wiki/Conscription "Conscription") for the first time in the
country's history as well as the raising of what was, at the time, the largest
all-volunteer army in history, known as [Kitchener's
Army](/wiki/Kitchener%27s_Army "Kitchener's Army"), of more than 2,000,000
men.[5]:504 The outbreak of war has generally been regarded as a socially
unifying event,[6] although this view has been challenged by more recent
scholarship. In any case, responses in Great Britain in 1914 were similar to
those amongst populations across Europe.[7]

On the eve of war, there was serious domestic unrest in the UK (amongst the
labour and suffrage movements and especially in Ireland) but much of the
population rapidly rallied behind the government. Significant sacrifices were
made in the name of defeating the Empire's enemies and many of those who could
not fight contributed to philanthropic and humanitarian causes. Fearing food
shortages and labour shortfalls, the government passed legislation such as the
[Defence of the Realm Act 1914](/wiki/Defence_of_the_Realm_Act_1914 "Defence
of the Realm Act 1914"), to give it new powers. The war saw a move away from
the idea of "[business as usual](/wiki/Business_as_usual_\(policy\) "Business
as usual \(policy\)")" under [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the
United Kingdom") [H. H. Asquith](/wiki/H._H._Asquith "H. H. Asquith"),[8] and
towards a state of [total war](/wiki/Total_war "Total war") (complete state
intervention in public affairs) under the premiership of [David Lloyd
George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David Lloyd George");[9] the first time this
had been seen in Britain. The war also witnessed the first [aerial
bombardments of cities in
Britain](/wiki/German_strategic_bombing_during_World_War_I "German strategic
bombing during World War I").

Newspapers played an important role in maintaining popular support for the
war.[10] Large quantities of propaganda were produced by the government under
the guidance of such journalists as [Charles
Masterman](/wiki/Charles_Masterman "Charles Masterman") and newspaper owners
such as [Lord Beaverbrook](/wiki/Max_Aitken,_1st_Baron_Beaverbrook "Max
Aitken, 1st Baron Beaverbrook"). By adapting to the changing demographics of
the workforce (or the "dilution of labour", as it was termed), war-related
industries grew rapidly, and production increased, as concessions were quickly
made to [trade unions](/wiki/Trade_union "Trade union").[11] In that regard,
the war is also credited by some with drawing women into mainstream employment
for the first time.[12] Debates continue about the impact the war had on
women's emancipation, given that a large number of women were granted the vote
for the first time in [1918](/wiki/1918_UK_general_election "1918 UK general
election"). The experience of individual women during the war varied; much
depended on locality, age, marital status and occupation.[13][14]

The civilian death rate rose due to food shortages and [Spanish
Flu](/wiki/Spanish_Flu "Spanish Flu"), which hit the country in 1918.[15]
Military deaths are estimated to have exceeded 850,000.[16] The Empire reached
its zenith at the conclusion of peace negotiations.[17] However, the war
heightened not only imperial loyalties but also individual national identities
in the Dominions (Canada, Newfoundland, Australia, New Zealand and South
Africa) and India. [Irish nationalists](/wiki/Irish_nationalists "Irish
nationalists") after 1916 moved from collaboration with London to demands for
immediate independence (see [Easter Rising](/wiki/Easter_Rising "Easter
Rising")), a move given great impetus by the [Conscription Crisis of
1918](/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1918 "Conscription Crisis of 1918").[18]

Military historians continue to debate matters of tactics and strategy.
However, in terms of memory of the war, historian Adrian Gregory argues that:

    "The verdict of popular culture is more or less unanimous. The First World War was stupid, tragic and futile. The stupidity of the war has been a theme of growing strength since the 1920s. From [Robert Graves](/wiki/Robert_Graves "Robert Graves"), through '[Oh! What a Lovely War](/wiki/Oh!_What_a_Lovely_War "Oh! What a Lovely War")' to '[Blackadder Goes Forth](/wiki/Blackadder_Goes_Forth "Blackadder Goes Forth"),' the criminal idiocy of the British High Command has become an article of faith."[19] Ireland did not want to be part of the British side they held a rebellion during the war

Herbert_Henry_Asquith.jpg)](/wiki/File:Herbert_Henry_Asquith.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Herbert_Henry_Asquith.jpg "Enlarge")

[H. H. Asquith](/wiki/H._H._Asquith "H. H. Asquith") (c. 1915), Prime Minister
at the beginning of the war

### Asquith as Prime
Minister[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Asquith as Prime Minister")]

Main article: [Asquith coalition ministry](/wiki/Asquith_coalition_ministry
"Asquith coalition ministry")

On 4 August, the King took Britain (and her Empire) into the Great War with H.
H. Asquith of the [Liberal Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_\(UK\) "Liberal Party
\(UK\)") as Prime Minister. Britain's reasons for declaring war were complex.

The ostensible reason given was that Britain was required to safeguard
Belgium's neutrality under the 1839 [Treaty of
London](/wiki/Treaty_of_London_\(1839\) "Treaty of London \(1839\)"). The
German invasion of Belgium was, therefore, the _[casus
belli](/wiki/Casus_belli "Casus belli")_ and, importantly, legitimized and
galvanized popular support for the war.

The strategic risk posed by German control of the Belgian and ultimately
French coast was considered unacceptable. German guarantees of post-war
behaviour were cast into doubt by her blasé treatment of Belgian neutrality.
However, the Treaty of London had not committed Britain on her own to
safeguard Belgium's neutrality. Moreover, naval war planning demonstrated that
Britain herself would have violated Belgian neutrality by blockading her ports
(to prevent imported goods passing to Germany) in the event of war with
Germany.

Britain's relationship with her Entente partners, both France and Russia, were
equally significant factors. The Foreign Secretary [Edward
Grey](/wiki/Edward_Grey,_1st_Viscount_Grey_of_Fallodon "Edward Grey, 1st
Viscount Grey of Fallodon") argued that the secret naval agreements with
France (although they had not been approved by the Cabinet) created a moral
obligation _vis a vis_ Britain and France. What is more, in the event that
Britain abandoned its Entente friends, it was feared that if Germany won the
war, or the Entente won without British support, then, either way, Britain
would be left without any friends. This would have left both Britain and her
Empire vulnerable to attack.

British Foreign office mandarin [Eyre Crowe](/wiki/Eyre_Crowe "Eyre Crowe")
said:

> "Should the war come, and England stand aside, one of two things must
> happen. (a) Either Germany and Austria win, crush France and humiliate
> Russia. What will be the position of a friendless England? (b) Or France and
> Russia win. What would be their attitude towards England? What about India
> and the Mediterranean?"[20]:544

The Liberal Party might have survived a short war, but the totality of the
Great War called for strong measures that the Party had long rejected. The
result was the permanent destruction of the ability of the Liberal Party to
lead a government. Historian [Robert Blake](/wiki/Robert_Blake,_Baron_Blake
"Robert Blake, Baron Blake") explains the dilemma:

    the Liberals were traditionally the party of freedom of speech, conscience and trade. They were against jingoism, heavy armaments and compulsion....Liberals were neither wholehearted nor unanimous about conscription, censorship, the [Defence of the Realm Act](/wiki/Defence_of_the_Realm_Act "Defence of the Realm Act"), severity toward aliens and pacifists, direction of labour and industry. The Conservatives... had no such misgivings.[21]

Blake further notes that it was the Liberals, not the Conservatives who needed
the moral outrage of Belgium to justify going to war, while the Conservatives
called for intervention from the start of the crisis on the grounds of
_[realpolitik](/wiki/Realpolitik "Realpolitik")_ and the balance of power.[22]

Asquith's Liberal government was brought down in May 1915, due in particular
to a [crisis in inadequate artillery shell
production](/wiki/Shell_Crisis_of_1915 "Shell Crisis of 1915") and the protest
resignation of [Jackie Fisher](/wiki/John_Fisher,_1st_Baron_Fisher "John
Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher") over the [Gallipoli
Campaign](/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign "Gallipoli Campaign") against Turkey.
Reluctant to face doom in an election, Asquith formed a new coalition
government on 25 May, with the majority of the new cabinet coming from his own
Liberal party and the [Unionist (Conservative)
party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_\(UK\) "Conservative Party \(UK\)"), along
with a token Labour representation. The new government lasted a year and a
half, and was the last time Liberals controlled the government.[23]

### Lloyd George as Prime
Minister[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Lloyd George as Prime Minister")]

Main article: [Lloyd George ministry](/wiki/Lloyd_George_ministry "Lloyd
George ministry")

This coalition government lasted until 1916, when the Unionists became
dissatisfied with Asquith and the Liberals' conduct of affairs, particularly
over the [Battle of the Somme](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme "Battle of the
Somme").[24] Asquith's opponents now took control, led by [Bonar
Law](/wiki/Bonar_Law "Bonar Law") (leader of the Conservatives), [Sir Edward
Carson](/wiki/Sir_Edward_Carson "Sir Edward Carson") (leader of the [Ulster
Unionists](/wiki/Ulster_Unionists "Ulster Unionists")), and [David Lloyd
George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David Lloyd George") (then a minister in the
cabinet). Law, who had few allies outside his own party, lacked sufficient
support to form a new coalition; the Liberal Lloyd George, on the other hand,
enjoyed much wider support and duly formed a majority-Conservative [coalition
government](/wiki/Coalition_Government_1916%E2%80%931922 "Coalition Government
1916–1922") with Lloyd George Liberals and Labour. Asquith was still the party
head but he and his followers moved to the opposition benches in
Parliament.[25]

Lloyd George immediately set about transforming the British war effort, taking
firm control of both military and domestic policy.[26][27] In the first 235
days of its existence, the War Cabinet met 200 times.[9] Its creation marked
the transition to a state of [total war](/wiki/Total_war "Total war")—the idea
that every man, woman and child should play his or her part in the war effort.
Moreover, it was decided that members of the government should be the men who
controlled the war effort, primarily utilising the power they had been given
under the [Defence of the Realm Act](/wiki/Defence_of_the_Realm_Act "Defence
of the Realm Act").[9] For the first time, the government could react quickly,
without endless bureaucracy to tie it down, and with up-to-date statistics on
such matters as the state of the [merchant navy](/wiki/Merchant_navy "Merchant
navy") and farm production.[9] The policy marked a distinct shift away from
Asquith's initial policy of [laissez-faire](/wiki/Laissez-faire "Laissez-
faire"),[8] which had been characterised by [Winston
Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill")'s declaration of
"[business as usual](/wiki/Business_as_usual_\(policy\) "Business as usual
\(policy\)")" in November 1914.[28] The success of Lloyd George's government
can also be attributed to a general lack of desire for an election, and the
practical absence of dissent that this brought about.[29]

[![Head and shoulders of a middle-aged gentleman with a bushy
moustache](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/LloydGeorge.jpg/220px-
LloydGeorge.jpg)](/wiki/File:LloydGeorge.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LloydGeorge.jpg "Enlarge")

David Lloyd George (c. 1920), prime minister at the end of the war

In rapid succession in spring 1918 came a series of military and political
crises.[30] The Germans, having moved troops from the Eastern front and
retrained them in new tactics, now had more soldiers on the Western Front than
the Allies. On 21 March 1918 Germany launched a full scale [Spring
Offensive](/wiki/Spring_Offensive "Spring Offensive") against the British and
French lines, hoping for victory on the battlefield before United States
troops arrived in large numbers. The Allied armies fell back 40 miles in
confusion, and facing defeat London realized it needed more troops to fight a
mobile war. Lloyd George found half a million soldiers and rushed them to
France, asked American President [Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson
"Woodrow Wilson") for immediate help, and agreed to the appointment of the
French Marshal Foch as commander in chief on the Western Front, so that Allied
forces could be coordinated to handle the German offensive.[31]

Despite strong warnings that it was a bad idea, the War Cabinet [decided to
impose conscription on Ireland](/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1918
"Conscription Crisis of 1918") in 1918. The main reason was that labour in
Britain demanded it as the price for cutting back on exemptions for certain
workers. Labour wanted the principle established that no one was exempt, but
it did not demand that conscription should actually take place in Ireland. The
proposal was enacted, but never enforced. The Roman Catholic bishops for the
first time entered the fray, calling for open resistance to compulsory
military service, while the majority of Irish nationalists moved to supporting
the intransigent [Sinn Féin](/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in "Sinn Féin") movement (away
from the constitutional [Irish National Party](/wiki/Irish_National_Party
"Irish National Party")). This proved a decisive moment, marking the end of
Irish willingness to stay inside the Union.[32][33]

On 7 May 1918, a senior army officer on active duty, Major-General [Sir
Frederick Maurice](/wiki/Frederick_Barton_Maurice "Frederick Barton Maurice"),
prompted [a second crisis](/wiki/Maurice_Debate "Maurice Debate") when he went
public with allegations that Lloyd George had lied to Parliament on military
matters. Asquith, the Liberal leader in the House, took up the allegations and
attacked Lloyd George (also a Liberal). While Asquith's presentation was poor,
Lloyd George vigorously defended his position, treating the debate as a vote
of confidence. He won over the House with a powerful refutation of Maurice's
allegations. The main results were to strengthen Lloyd George, weaken Asquith,
end public criticism of overall strategy, and strengthen civilian control of
the military.[34][35] Meanwhile, the German offensive stalled and was
ultimately reversed. Victory came on 11 November 1918.[36]

Historian George H. Cassar has evaluated Lloyd George's legacy as a war
leader:

    After all that has been said and done, what are we to make of Lloyd George’s legacy as a war leader? On the home front he achieved varied results in tackling difficult, and in some instances, unprecedented problems. It would be hard to have improved on his dealings with labour and the program to increase homegrown food, but in the sectors of manpower, price control and food distribution he adopted the same approach as his predecessor, taking action only in response to the changing nature of the conflict. In the vital area of national morale, while he did not have the technical advantages of Churchill, his personal conduct damaged his ability to do more to inspire the nation. All things considered, it is unlikely that any of his political contemporaries could have handled matters at home as effectively as he did, although it can be argued that if someone else had been in charge, the difference would not have been sufficient to change the final outcome. In his conduct of the war he did advance the cause of the Entente significantly in some ways, but in determining strategy, one of the most important tasks for which a prime minister must be responsible, he was undeniably a failure. To sum up, while Lord George's contributions outweighed his mistakes, the margin is too narrow, in my opinion, to include him In the pantheon of Britain's outstanding war leaders.[37]

### Collapse of the Liberal
Party[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Collapse of the Liberal Party")]

In the [general election of 1918](/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_1918
"United Kingdom general election, 1918"), Lloyd George, "the Man Who Won the
War", led his coalition into another _[khaki election](/wiki/Khaki_election
"Khaki election")_ and won a sweeping victory over the Asquithian Liberals and
the newly emerging [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_\(UK\) "Labour Party
\(UK\)"). Lloyd George and the Conservative leader [Bonar Law](/wiki/Bonar_Law
"Bonar Law") wrote a joint letter of support to candidates to indicate they
were considered the official Coalition candidates – this
["coupon"](/wiki/The_Coalition_Coupon "The Coalition Coupon"), as it became
known, was issued to opponents of many sitting Liberal MPs, devastating the
incumbents.[38] Asquith and most of his Liberal colleagues lost their seats.
Lloyd George was increasingly under the influence of the rejuvenated
Conservative party. The Liberal party never recovered.[39]

###
Finance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Finance")]

Before the war, the government spent 13 percent of [gross national
product](/wiki/Gross_national_product "Gross national product") (GNP); in 1918
it spent 59 percent of GNP. The war was financed by borrowing large sums at
home and abroad, by new taxes, and by inflation. It was implicitly financed by
postponing maintenance and repair, and cancelling unneeded projects.[40] The
government avoided indirect taxes because they raised the cost of living, and
caused discontent among the working class. In 1913-14, indirect taxes on
tobacco and alcohol yielded £75 million, while direct taxes yielded £88
million, including an income tax of £44 million and estate duties of £22
million. That is, 54 percent of revenue came from direct taxes; by 1918,
direct taxes were 80 percent of revenue.[41] There was a strong emphasis on
being "fair" and being "scientific." The public generally supported the heavy
new taxes, with minimal complaints. The Treasury rejected proposals for a
stiff capital levy, which the Labour Party wanted to use to weaken the
capitalists. Instead, there was an excess profits tax, of 50 percent of
profits above the normal prewar level; the rate was raised to 80 percent in
1917.[42][43] Excise taxes were added on luxury imports such as automobiles,
clocks and watches. There was no sales tax or value added tax. The main
increase in revenue came from income tax, which in 1915 went up to 3s. 6d in
the pound (17.5%), and individual exemptions were lowered. The income tax rate
grew to 5s in the pound (25%) in 1916, and 6s (30%) in 1918. Altogether, taxes
provided at most 30 percent of national expenditure, with the rest from
borrowing. The national debt soared from £625 million to £7,800 million.
Government bonds typically paid five percent. Inflation escalated so that the
pound in 1919 purchased only a third of the basket it had purchased it 1914.
Wages were laggard, and the poor and retired were especially hard hit.[44][45]

##
Monarchy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Monarchy")]

[![A man, wearing a crown and holding a broom, sweeps away a collection of
other
crowns](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/A_Good_Riddance_-
_George_V_of_the_United_Kingdom_cartoon_in_Punch%2C_1917.png/220px-
A_Good_Riddance_-
_George_V_of_the_United_Kingdom_cartoon_in_Punch%2C_1917.png)](/wiki/File:A_Good_Riddance_-
_George_V_of_the_United_Kingdom_cartoon_in_Punch,_1917.png)

[](/wiki/File:A_Good_Riddance_-
_George_V_of_the_United_Kingdom_cartoon_in_Punch,_1917.png "Enlarge")

"A good riddance"  
A 1917 _[Punch](/wiki/Punch_\(magazine\) "Punch \(magazine\)")_ cartoon
depicts King George sweeping away his German titles.

Further information: [George V § First World
War](/wiki/George_V#First_World_War "George V")

The British Royal Family faced a serious problem during the First World War
because of its blood ties to the ruling family of Germany, Britain's prime
adversary in the war. Before the war, the British royal family had been known
as the [House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha](/wiki/House_of_Saxe-Coburg_and_Gotha
"House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha"). In 1910, [George V](/wiki/George_V "George
V") became King on the death of his father, [King Edward VII](/wiki/Edward_VII
"Edward VII"), and remained king throughout the war. He was the [first
cousin](/wiki/Cousin_chart "Cousin chart") of the German Kaiser [Wilhelm
II](/wiki/William_II,_German_Emperor "William II, German Emperor"), who came
to symbolise all the horrors of the war. [Queen Mary](/wiki/Mary_of_Teck "Mary
of Teck"), although British like her mother, was the daughter of the [Duke of
Teck](/wiki/Duke_of_Teck "Duke of Teck"), a descendant of the German [Royal
House of Württemberg](/wiki/Rulers_of_W%C3%BCrttemberg "Rulers of
Württemberg"). During the war [H. G. Wells](/wiki/H._G._Wells "H. G. Wells")
wrote about Britain's "alien and uninspiring court", and George famously
replied: "I may be uninspiring, but I'll be damned if I'm alien."[46]

On 17 July 1917, to appease British nationalist feelings, King George issued
an [Order in Council](/wiki/Order_in_Council "Order in Council") that changed
the name of the [British Royal Family](/wiki/British_Royal_Family "British
Royal Family") to the [House of Windsor](/wiki/House_of_Windsor "House of
Windsor"). He specifically adopted Windsor as the surname for all descendants
of [Queen Victoria](/wiki/Victoria_of_the_United_Kingdom "Victoria of the
United Kingdom") then living in Britain, excluding women who married into
other families and their descendants.[47] He and his relatives who were
British subjects relinquished the use of all German titles and styles, and
adopted English surnames. George compensated several of his male relatives by
creating them British peers. Thus, his cousin, [Prince Louis of
Battenberg](/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Marquess_of_Milford_Haven "Louis
Mountbatten, 1st Marquess of Milford Haven"), became the Marquess of Milford
Haven, while his brother-in-law, the [Duke of
Teck](/wiki/Adolphus_Cambridge,_1st_Marquess_of_Cambridge "Adolphus Cambridge,
1st Marquess of Cambridge"), became the Marquess of Cambridge. Others, such as
[Princess Marie Louise of Schleswig-
Holstein](/wiki/Princess_Marie_Louise_of_Schleswig-Holstein "Princess Marie
Louise of Schleswig-Holstein") and [Princess Helena Victoria of Schleswig-
Holstein](/wiki/Princess_Helena_Victoria_of_Schleswig-Holstein "Princess
Helena Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein"), simply stopped using their
territorial designations. The system for titling members of the royal family
was also simplified.[48] Relatives of the British royal family who fought on
the German side were simply cut off; their British peerages were suspended by
a 1919 Order in Council under the provisions of the [Titles Deprivation Act
1917](/wiki/Titles_Deprivation_Act_1917 "Titles Deprivation Act 1917").[49]

[![Two look-alike men. Both wear beards and are in full military regalia
festooned with medals—one uniform dark, the other
white.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/84/Tsar_Nicholas_II_%26_King_George_V.JPG/220px-
Tsar_Nicholas_II_%26_King_George_V.JPG)](/wiki/File:Tsar_Nicholas_II_%26_King_George_V.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Tsar_Nicholas_II_%26_King_George_V.JPG "Enlarge")

King George V (right) with his first cousin [Tsar Nicholas
II](/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia "Nicholas II of Russia"), Berlin, 1913

Developments in Russia posed another set of issues for the monarchy. [Tsar
Nicholas II of Russia](/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia "Nicholas II of Russia")
was King George's first cousin and the two monarchs looked very much
alike.[50] When Nicholas was overthrown in the [Russian Revolution of
1917](/wiki/Russian_Revolution_of_1917 "Russian Revolution of 1917"), the
liberal Russian Government asked that the tsar and his family be given asylum
in Britain. The cabinet agreed but the king was worried that public opinion
was hostile and said no. It is likely the tsar would have refused to leave
Russia in any case. He remained and in 1918 he and his family were ordered
killed by Lenin, the Bolshevik leader.[51][52]

The [Prince of Wales](/wiki/Prince_of_Wales "Prince of Wales") – the future
[Edward VIII](/wiki/Edward_VIII "Edward VIII") – was keen to participate in
the war but the government refused to allow it, citing the immense harm that
would occur if the heir to the throne were captured.[53] Despite this, Edward
witnessed trench warfare at first hand and attempted to visit the front line
as often as he could, for which he was awarded the [Military
Cross](/wiki/Military_Cross "Military Cross") in 1916. His role in the war,
although limited, led to his great popularity among veterans of the
conflict.[54][55]

[![Five men, all in immaculate naval dress, stand on
deck.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Beatty_Rodman_KingGeorgeV_KingEdwardVIII_Sims.jpg/220px-
Beatty_Rodman_KingGeorgeV_KingEdwardVIII_Sims.jpg)](/wiki/File:Beatty_Rodman_KingGeorgeV_KingEdwardVIII_Sims.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Beatty_Rodman_KingGeorgeV_KingEdwardVIII_Sims.jpg "Enlarge")

[King George V](/wiki/George_V "George V") and his son the [Prince of
Wales](/wiki/Edward_VIII "Edward VIII") visiting the Grand Fleet in 1918. From
left to right: Admiral [David Beatty](/wiki/David_Beatty,_1st_Earl_Beatty
"David Beatty, 1st Earl Beatty"), [RN](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy"); Rear
Admiral [Hugh Rodman](/wiki/Hugh_Rodman "Hugh Rodman"), [USN](/wiki/USN
"USN"); King George V; Prince of Wales; Vice Admiral [William S.
Sims](/wiki/William_S._Sims "William S. Sims"), USN

Other members of the royal family were similarly involved. Prince Albert,
[Duke of York](/wiki/Duke_of_York "Duke of York") (later [George
VI](/wiki/George_VI "George VI")), was commissioned in the Royal Navy and saw
action as a turret officer aboard [HMS
_Collingwood_](/wiki/HMS_Collingwood_\(1908\) "HMS Collingwood \(1908\)") at
the [battle of Jutland](/wiki/Battle_of_Jutland "Battle of Jutland") but saw
no further action in the war, largely because of ill health.[56] [Princess
Mary](/wiki/Mary,_Princess_Royal_and_Countess_of_Harewood "Mary, Princess
Royal and Countess of Harewood"), the King's only daughter, visited hospitals
and welfare organisations with her mother, assisting with projects to give
comfort to British servicemen and assistance to their families. One of these
projects was [Princess Mary's _Christmas Gift
Fund_](/wiki/Princess_Mary_Christmas_gift_box "Princess Mary Christmas gift
box"), through which £162,000 worth of gifts was sent to all British soldiers
and sailors for Christmas 1914.[57] She took an active role in promoting the
[Girl Guide](/wiki/Girlguiding_UK "Girlguiding UK") movement, the [Voluntary
Aid Detachment](/wiki/Voluntary_Aid_Detachment "Voluntary Aid Detachment")
(VAD), the [Land Girls](/wiki/Women%27s_Land_Army "Women's Land Army") and in
1918, she took a nursing course and went to work at [Great Ormond Street
Hospital](/wiki/Great_Ormond_Street_Hospital "Great Ormond Street
Hospital").[58]

## Defence of the Realm
Act[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Defence of the Realm Act")]

Main article: [Defence of the Realm Act
1914](/wiki/Defence_of_the_Realm_Act_1914 "Defence of the Realm Act 1914")

The first Defence of the Realm Act (DORA) was passed on 8 August 1914, during
the early weeks of the war,[59] though in the next few months its provisions
were extended.[60] It gave the [government](/wiki/British_government "British
government") wide-ranging powers,[60] such as the ability to
[requisition](/wiki/Eminent_domain "Eminent domain") buildings or land needed
for the [war effort](/wiki/War_effort "War effort").[61] Some of the things
the British public were prohibited from doing included loitering under railway
bridges,[62] feeding wild animals[63] and discussing naval and military
matters.[64] [British Summer Time](/wiki/British_Summer_Time "British Summer
Time") was also introduced.[65] Alcoholic beverages were now to be watered
down, pub closing times were brought forward from 12.30 am to 10 pm, and, from
August 1916, Londoners were no longer able to whistle for a
[cab](/wiki/Cabriolet_\(carriage\) "Cabriolet \(carriage\)") between 10 pm and
7 am.[65] It has been criticised for both its strength and its use of the
[death penalty](/wiki/Death_penalty "Death penalty") as a
[deterrent](/wiki/Deterrence_\(legal\) "Deterrence \(legal\)")[66] – although
the act itself did not refer to the death penalty, it made provision for
civilians breaking these rules to be tried in army [courts
martial](/wiki/Court_martial "Court martial"), where the maximum penalty was
death.[67]

## Armed
forces[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Armed forces")]

###
Army[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Army")]

[![A large throng of people congregate, surrounded by police officers.
Approximately half wear peaked caps; the rest wear boaters. Some smile, the
rest look
pensive.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/220px-
British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg)](/wiki/File:British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg "Enlarge")

August 1914: London army volunteers await their pay at [St. Martin-in-the-
Fields](/wiki/St._Martin-in-the-Fields "St. Martin-in-the-Fields")

The [British Army during World War I](/wiki/British_Army_during_World_War_I
"British Army during World War I") was small in size when compared to the
other major European powers. In 1914, the British had a small, largely urban
English, volunteer force[68] of 400,000 soldiers, almost half of whom were
posted overseas to garrison the British Empire. (In August 1914, 74 of the 157
infantry battalions and 12 of the 31 cavalry regiments were posted
overseas.[5]:504) This total included the Regular Army and reservists in the
[Territorial Force](/wiki/Territorial_Force "Territorial Force").[5]:504
Together they formed the [British Expeditionary
Force](/wiki/British_Expeditionary_Force_\(World_War_I\) "British
Expeditionary Force \(World War I\)") (BEF),[69] for service in France and
became known as the [Old Contemptibles](/wiki/Old_Contemptibles "Old
Contemptibles"). The mass of volunteers in 1914–1915, popularly known as
[Kitchener's Army](/wiki/Kitchener%27s_Army "Kitchener's Army"), was destined
to go into action at the [battle of the Somme](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme
"Battle of the Somme").[5]:504 In January 1916, conscription was introduced,
and by the end of 1918, the army had reached its peak of strength of four
million men.[5]:504

### Royal
Navy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Royal Navy")]

Further information: [Naval warfare of World War
I](/wiki/Naval_warfare_of_World_War_I "Naval warfare of World War I")

[![Four battleships at
sea](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/2nd_Battle_Squadron.jpg/220px-2nd_Battle_Squadron.jpg)](/wiki/File:2nd_Battle_Squadron.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2nd_Battle_Squadron.jpg "Enlarge")

Ships of the 2nd Battle Squadron of the Royal Navy's Grand Fleet

The Royal Navy at the start of the war was the largest navy in the world due,
for the most part, to the [Naval Defence Act
1889](/wiki/Naval_Defence_Act_1889 "Naval Defence Act 1889") and the [two-
power standard](/wiki/History_of_the_Royal_Navy#Two-power_standard" "History
of the Royal Navy") which called for the navy to maintain a number of
battleships such as their strength was at least equal to the combined strength
of the next two largest navies in the world, which at that point were
[France](/wiki/French_navy#19th_century_revival "French navy") and
[Russia](/wiki/Russian_Navy#Imperial_Russian_Navy "Russian Navy").[70]

The major part of the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy")'s strength
was deployed at home in the [Grand Fleet](/wiki/British_Grand_Fleet "British
Grand Fleet"), with the primary aim of drawing the [German High Seas
Fleet](/wiki/Hochseeflotte "Hochseeflotte") into an engagement. No decisive
victory ever came. The Royal Navy and the [German Imperial
Navy](/wiki/Kaiserliche_Marine "Kaiserliche Marine") did come into contact,
notably in the [Battle of Heligoland
Bight](/wiki/Battle_of_Heligoland_\(1914\) "Battle of Heligoland \(1914\)"),
and at the [Battle of Jutland](/wiki/Battle_of_Jutland "Battle of
Jutland").[71] In view of their inferior numbers and firepower, the Germans
devised a plan to draw part of the British fleet into a trap and put it into
effect at Jutland in May 1916, but the result was inconclusive. In August
1916, the High Seas Fleet tried a similar enticement operation and was "lucky
to escape annihilation".[72] The lessons learned by the Royal Navy at Jutland
made it a more effective force in the future.[72]

In 1914, the navy had also formed the [63rd (Royal Naval)
Division](/wiki/63rd_\(Royal_Naval\)_Division "63rd \(Royal Naval\) Division")
from reservists, and this served extensively in the Mediterranean and on the
[Western Front](/wiki/Western_Front_\(World_War_I\) "Western Front \(World War
I\)").[73] Almost half of the Royal Navy casualties during the War were
sustained by this division, fighting on land and not at sea.[71]

### British air
services[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: British air services")]

Further information: [Royal Flying Corps](/wiki/Royal_Flying_Corps "Royal
Flying Corps") and [Royal Naval Air Service](/wiki/Royal_Naval_Air_Service
"Royal Naval Air Service")

[![A poster reads "ROYAL FLYING CORPS", "MILITARY WING", "VACANCIES EXIST",
information about pay, "GOD SAVE THE
KING".](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Royal_Flying_Corps_poster.jpg/220px-
Royal_Flying_Corps_poster.jpg)](/wiki/File:Royal_Flying_Corps_poster.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Royal_Flying_Corps_poster.jpg "Enlarge")

[Royal Flying Corps](/wiki/Royal_Flying_Corps "Royal Flying Corps")
recruitment poster

At the start of the war, the Royal Flying Corps (RFC), commanded by [David
Henderson](/wiki/David_Henderson_\(British_Army_officer\) "David Henderson
\(British Army officer\)"), was sent to France and was first used for aerial
spotting in September 1914, but only became efficient when they perfected the
use of [wireless communication](/wiki/Wireless "Wireless") at [Aubers
Ridge](/wiki/Aubers_Ridge "Aubers Ridge") on 9 May 1915\. [Aerial
photography](/wiki/Aerial_photography "Aerial photography") was attempted
during 1914, but again only became effective the next year. In 1915 [Hugh
Trenchard](/wiki/Hugh_Trenchard "Hugh Trenchard") replaced Henderson and the
RFC adopted an aggressive posture. By 1918, photographic images could be taken
from 15,000 feet (4,600 m), and interpreted by over 3,000 personnel. Planes
did not carry [parachutes](/wiki/Parachute "Parachute") until 1918, though
they had been available since before the war.[74] On 17 August 1917, General
[Jan Smuts](/wiki/Jan_Smuts "Jan Smuts") presented a report to the War Council
on the future of [air power](/wiki/Aerial_warfare "Aerial warfare"). Because
of its potential for the 'devastation of enemy lands and the destruction of
industrial and populous centres on a vast scale', he recommended a new air
service be formed that would be on a level with the army and navy. The
formation of the new service however would make the under utilised men and
machines of the [Royal Naval Air Service](/wiki/Royal_Naval_Air_Service "Royal
Naval Air Service") (RNAS) available for action across [the Western
Front](/wiki/Western_Front_\(World_War_I\) "Western Front \(World War I\)"),
as well as ending the inter-service rivalries that at times had adversely
affected aircraft procurement. On 1 April 1918, the RFC and the RNAS were
amalgamated to form a new service, the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force
"Royal Air Force") (RAF).[75]

## Recruitment and
conscription[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Recruitment and conscription")]

Main article: [Recruitment to the British Army during the First World
War](/wiki/Recruitment_to_the_British_Army_during_the_First_World_War
"Recruitment to the British Army during the First World War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Britain_Needs_You_at_Once_-
_WWI_recruitment_poster_-
_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_Poster_No._108.jpg/200px-
Britain_Needs_You_at_Once_-_WWI_recruitment_poster_-
_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_Poster_No._108.jpg)](/wiki/File:Britain_Needs_You_at_Once_-
_WWI_recruitment_poster_-
_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_Poster_No._108.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Britain_Needs_You_at_Once_-_WWI_recruitment_poster_-
_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_Poster_No._108.jpg "Enlarge")

Poster by the Parliamentary Recruiting Committee, featuring [St. George and
the Dragon](/wiki/St._George_and_the_Dragon "St. George and the Dragon").

Particularly in the early stages of the war, many men, for a wide variety of
reasons, decided to "join up" to the armed forces—by 5 September 1914, over
225,000 had signed up to fight for what became known as [Kitchener's
Army](/wiki/Kitchener%27s_Army "Kitchener's Army").[76] Over the course of the
war, a number of factors contributed to recruitment rates, including
patriotism, the work of the Parliamentary Recruiting Committee in producing
posters, dwindling alternative employment opportunities, and an eagerness for
adventure to escape humdrum routine.[76] [Pals
battalions](/wiki/Pals_battalions "Pals battalions"), where whole battalions
were raised from a small geographic area or employer, also proved popular.
Higher recruitment rates were seen in Wales and Scotland, though in the case
of the Welsh and Irish, political tensions tended to "put something of a
blight upon enlistment".[76]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/94/Lawson_Wood_-
_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_-
_Your_King_%26_Country_Need_You.jpg/220px-Lawson_Wood_-
_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_-
_Your_King_%26_Country_Need_You.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lawson_Wood_-
_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_-_Your_King_%26_Country_Need_You.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lawson_Wood_-_Parliamentary_Recruiting_Committee_-
_Your_King_%26_Country_Need_You.jpg "Enlarge")

A 1914 poster shows a Scottish soldier in Belgium, in response to Germany
describing the [Treaty of London](/wiki/Treaty_of_London_\(1839\) "Treaty of
London \(1839\)"), which protected Belgium's independence and neutrality, as a
"scrap of paper" when they invaded in August 1914.[77]

Recruitment remained fairly steady through 1914 and early 1915, but fell
dramatically during the later years, especially after the [Somme
campaign](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme "Battle of the Somme"), which resulted in
500,000 casualties. As a result,
[conscription](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_Kingdom "Conscription in the
United Kingdom") was introduced for the first time in January 1916 for single
men, and extended in May–June to all men aged 18 to 41 across England, Wales
and Scotland, by way of the _[Military Service
Acts](/wiki/Military_Service_Act_\(United_Kingdom\) "Military Service Act
\(United Kingdom\)")_.[76][78]

Urban centres, with their poverty and unemployment were favourite recruiting
grounds of the regular British army. Dundee, where the female dominated jute
industry limited male employment had one of the highest proportion of
reservists and serving soldiers than almost any other British city.[79]
Concern for their families' standard of living made men hesitate to enlist;
voluntary enlistment rates went up after the government guaranteed a weekly
stipend for life to the survivors of men who were killed or disabled.[80]
After the introduction of conscription from January 1916 every part of the
country was affected.

The policy of relying on volunteers had sharply reduced the capacity of heavy
industry to produce the munitions needed for the war. Historian [R. J. Q.
Adams](/wiki/R._J._Q._Adams "R. J. Q. Adams") reports that 19% of the men in
the iron and steel industry entered the Army, 22% of the miners, 20% in the
engineering trades, 24% in the electrical industries, 16% among small arms
craftsmen, and 24% of the men who had been engaged in making high
explosives.[81] In response critical industries were prioritised over the army
("reserved occupations"), including munitions, food production and merchant
shipping.[76]

### Conscription Crisis of
1918[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Conscription Crisis of 1918")]

Main article: [Conscription Crisis of 1918](/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1918
"Conscription Crisis of 1918")

In April 1918 legislation was brought forward which allowed for extension of
conscription to Ireland.[76] Though this ultimately never materialised, the
effect was "disastrous".[76] Despite significant numbers [volunteering for
Irish regiments](/wiki/Ireland_in_World_War_I "Ireland in World War I"),[76]
the idea of _enforced_ conscription proved unpopular. The reaction was based
particularly on the fact that implementation of conscription in Ireland was
linked to a pledged "measure of self-government in Ireland".[82] The linking
of conscription and [Home Rule](/wiki/Government_of_Ireland_Act_1914
"Government of Ireland Act 1914") in this way outraged the Irish parties at
Westminster, who walked out in protest and returned to Ireland to organise
opposition.[83] As a result, a general strike was called, and on 23 April
1918, work was stopped in railways, docks, factories, mills, theatres,
cinemas, trams, public services, shipyards, newspapers, shops, and even
official munitions factories. The strike was described as "complete and
entire, an unprecedented event outside the [continental
countries](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe")".[84] Ultimately the
effect was a total loss of interest in Home Rule and of popular support for
the nationalist [Irish Party](/wiki/Irish_Parliamentary_Party "Irish
Parliamentary Party") who were defeated outright by the separatist republican
[Sinn Féin](/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in "Sinn Féin") party in the December 1918
[Irish general election](/wiki/Irish_general_election,_1918 "Irish general
election, 1918"), one of the precursors of the [Anglo-Irish War](/wiki/Anglo-
Irish_War "Anglo-Irish War").

### Conscientious
objectors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Conscientious objectors")]

Further information: [Conscientious objector § United
Kingdom](/wiki/Conscientious_objector#United_Kingdom "Conscientious objector")

The conscription legislation introduced the right to refuse military service,
allowing for conscientious objectors to be absolutely exempted, to perform
alternative [civilian service](/wiki/Civilian_service "Civilian service"), or
to serve as a [non-combatant](/wiki/Non-combatant "Non-combatant") in the
army, according to the extent to which they could convince a Military Service
Tribunal of the quality of their objection.[85] Around 16,500 men were
recorded as conscientious objectors,[76] with [Quakers](/wiki/Quakers
"Quakers") playing a large role.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] 4,500
objectors were sent to work on farms to undertake "work of national
importance", 7,000 were ordered non-combatant duties as stretcher bearers, but
6,000 were forced into the army, and when they refused orders, they were sent
to prison, as in the case of the [Richmond Sixteen](/wiki/Richmond_Sixteen
"Richmond Sixteen").[86] Some 843 conscientious objectors spent more than two
years in prison; ten died while there, seventeen were initially given the
death penalty (but received life imprisonment) and 142 were imprisoned on life
sentences.[87] Conscientious objectors who were deemed not to have made any
useful contribution were [disenfranchised](/wiki/Disfranchisement
"Disfranchisement") for five years after the war.[85]

## Naval and air
raids[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Naval and air raids")]

[![A map of England, with towns bombarded during the war marked. All are in
the
east.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/WWI_German_targets_in_England_%28zoomed%29.png/220px-
WWI_German_targets_in_England_%28zoomed%29.png)](/wiki/File:WWI_German_targets_in_England_\(zoomed\).png)

[](/wiki/File:WWI_German_targets_in_England_\(zoomed\).png "Enlarge")

German bombardments were concentrated on the east coast of England

At the start of the First World War, for the first time since the [Napoleonic
Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars"), the population of the British
Isles was in danger of attack from naval raids. The country also came under
attack from air raids by [zeppelins](/wiki/Zeppelins "Zeppelins") and [fixed-
wing aircraft](/wiki/Fixed-wing_aircraft "Fixed-wing aircraft"), another
first.[5]:709[88]

### Naval
raids[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Naval raids")]

Main articles: [Raid on Yarmouth](/wiki/Raid_on_Yarmouth "Raid on Yarmouth")
and [Raid on Scarborough, Hartlepool and
Whitby](/wiki/Raid_on_Scarborough,_Hartlepool_and_Whitby "Raid on Scarborough,
Hartlepool and Whitby")

The Raid on Yarmouth, which took place in November 1914, was an attack by the
German Navy on the British [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea") port and
town of [Great Yarmouth](/wiki/Great_Yarmouth "Great Yarmouth"). Little damage
was done to the town itself, since shells only landed on the beach once German
ships laying [mines](/wiki/Naval_mine "Naval mine") offshore were interrupted
by British destroyers. One British [submarine](/wiki/Submarine "Submarine")
was sunk by a mine as it attempted to leave harbour and attack the German
ships, while one German [armoured cruiser](/wiki/Armored_cruiser "Armored
cruiser") was sunk after striking two mines outside its own home port.[89]

[![Britannia stands in front of a group of men holding various armaments,
looking out over a scene of burning houses. The caption reads "REMEMBER
SCARBOROUGH!", "ENLIST
NOW".](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/89/Rememberscarborough.jpg/220px-
Rememberscarborough.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rememberscarborough.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rememberscarborough.jpg "Enlarge")

British propaganda fuelled by the German raid on Scarborough

In December 1914, the German navy carried out attacks on the British coastal
towns of [Scarborough](/wiki/Scarborough,_North_Yorkshire "Scarborough, North
Yorkshire"), [Hartlepool](/wiki/Hartlepool "Hartlepool") and
[Whitby](/wiki/Whitby "Whitby"). The attack resulted in 137 fatalities and 593
casualties,[90] many of which were civilians. The attack made the German navy
very unpopular with the British public, as an attack against British
[civilians](/wiki/Civilian "Civilian") in their homes. Likewise, the British
Royal Navy was criticised for failing to prevent the raid.[91][92]

### Bombardment of Yarmouth and
Lowestoft[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Bombardment of Yarmouth and Lowestoft")]

Main article: [Bombardment of Yarmouth and
Lowestoft](/wiki/Bombardment_of_Yarmouth_and_Lowestoft "Bombardment of
Yarmouth and Lowestoft")

In April 1916 a German battlecruiser squadron with accompanying cruisers and
destroyers bombarded the coastal ports of Yarmouth and Lowestoft. Although the
ports had some military importance, the main aim of the raid was to entice out
defending ships which could then be picked off either by the battlecruiser
squadron or by the full High Seas Fleet, which was stationed at sea ready to
intervene if an opportunity presented itself. The result was inconclusive:
nearby Royal Navy units were too small to intervene so largely kept clear of
the German battlecruisers, and the German ships withdrew before the first
British fast response battlecruiser squadron or the Grand Fleet could
arrive.[93]

[![Poster: picture of Zeppelin illuminated by searchlight over silhouetted
London skyline; headline: "IT IS FAR BETTER TO FACE THE BULLETS THAN TO BE
KILLED AT HOME BY A
BOMB"](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/It_is_far_better_to_face_the_bullets.jpg/220px-
It_is_far_better_to_face_the_bullets.jpg)](/wiki/File:It_is_far_better_to_face_the_bullets.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:It_is_far_better_to_face_the_bullets.jpg "Enlarge")

British propaganda poster from 1915, drawing on the fear of zeppelin attacks
to aid recruitment

### Air
raids[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Air raids")]

Further information: [Zeppelins in World War I](/wiki/Zeppelin#WW1 "Zeppelin")

German [zeppelins](/wiki/Zeppelins "Zeppelins") bombed towns on the east
coast, starting on 19 January 1915 with [Great Yarmouth](/wiki/Great_Yarmouth
"Great Yarmouth").[94] London was also hit later in the same year, on 31
May.[94] [Propaganda](/wiki/Propaganda "Propaganda") supporting the British
war effort often used these raids to their advantage: one recruitment poster
claimed: "It is far better to face the bullets than to be killed at home by a
bomb" (see image). The reaction from the public, however, was mixed; whilst
10,000 visited [Scarborough](/wiki/Scarborough,_North_Yorkshire "Scarborough,
North Yorkshire") to view the damage there, London theatres reported having
fewer visitors during periods of "Zeppelin weather"—dark, fine nights.[94]

Throughout 1917 [Germany](/wiki/Imperial_Germany "Imperial Germany") began to
deploy increasing numbers of [fixed-wing](/wiki/Fixed-wing_aircraft "Fixed-
wing aircraft") [bombers](/wiki/Bombers "Bombers"), the [Gotha
G.IV](/wiki/Gotha_G.IV "Gotha G.IV")'s first target being
[Folkestone](/wiki/Folkestone "Folkestone") on 25 May 1917, following this
attack the number of airship raids decreased rapidly in favour of raids by
fixed wing aircraft,[94] before Zeppelin raids were called off entirely. In
total, Zeppelins dropped 6,000 bombs, resulting in 556 dead and 1,357
wounded.[95] Soon after the raid on Folkestone, the bombers began raids on
London: one daylight raid on 13 June 1917 by 14 Gothas caused 162 deaths in
the [East End of London](/wiki/East_End_of_London "East End of London").[94]
In response to this new threat, [Major General Edward Bailey
Ashmore](/wiki/Edward_Ashmore_\(British_Army_officer\) "Edward Ashmore
\(British Army officer\)"), a RFC pilot who later commanded an
[artillery](/wiki/Artillery "Artillery")
[division](/wiki/Division_\(military\) "Division \(military\)") in Belgium,
was appointed to devise an improved system of detection, communication and
control,[96] The system, called the _Metropolitan Observation Service_ ,
encompassed the [London Air Defence Area](/wiki/London_Air_Defence_Area
"London Air Defence Area") and would later extend eastwards towards the
[Kentish](/wiki/Kent "Kent") and [Essex](/wiki/Essex "Essex") coasts. The
Metropolitan Observation Service was fully operational until the late summer
of 1918 (the last German bombing raid taking place on 19 May 1918).[97] During
the war, the Germans carried out 51 airship raids and 52 fixed-wing bomber
raids on England, which together dropped 280 tons of bombs. The casualties
amounted to 1,413 killed, and 3,409 wounded.[98] The success of anti-air
defence measures was limited; of the 397 aircraft that had taken part in
raids, only 24 Gothas were shot down (though 37 more were lost in accidents),
despite an estimated rate of 14,540 anti-air rounds per aircraft. Anti-
zeppelin defences were more successful, with 17 shot down and 21 lost in
accidents.[94]

##
Media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Media")]

###
Propaganda[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Propaganda")]

Main article: [British propaganda during World War
I](/wiki/British_propaganda_during_World_War_I "British propaganda during
World War I")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Stanford%E2%80%99s_Geographical_Establishment%2C_What_Germany_Wants_1917_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1199_01.jpg/220px-
Stanford%E2%80%99s_Geographical_Establishment%2C_What_Germany_Wants_1917_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1199_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stanford%E2%80%99s_Geographical_Establishment,_What_Germany_Wants_1917_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1199_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stanford%E2%80%99s_Geographical_Establishment,_What_Germany_Wants_1917_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1199_01.jpg
"Enlarge")

A world map showing territory that "Germany Wants" by Edward Stanford. 1917.
Close reading of the quoted material shows that the map is misleading: it
implies that Germany plans to annex all the territory in red, but this is only
the case for a small fraction of it.

[Propaganda](/wiki/Propaganda "Propaganda") and censorship were closely linked
during the war.[99] The need to maintain morale and counter German propaganda
was recognised early in the war and the [War Propaganda
Bureau](/wiki/War_Propaganda_Bureau "War Propaganda Bureau") was established
under the leadership of [Charles Masterman](/wiki/Charles_Masterman "Charles
Masterman") in September 1914.[99] The Bureau enlisted eminent writers such as
[H G Wells](/wiki/H_G_Wells "H G Wells"), [Arthur Conan
Doyle](/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle "Arthur Conan Doyle"), [Rudyard
Kipling](/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling "Rudyard Kipling") as well as newspaper
editors. Until its abolition in 1917, the department published 300 books and
pamphlets in 21 languages, distributed over 4,000 propaganda photographs every
week, and circulated maps, cartoons, and lantern slides to the media.[100]
Masterman also commissioned films about the war such as [The Battle of the
Somme](/wiki/The_Battle_of_the_Somme_\(film\) "The Battle of the Somme
\(film\)"), which appeared in August 1916, while the battle was still in
progress as a morale-booster and in general it met with a favourable
reception. _The Times_ reported on 22 August 1916 that "Crowded audiences ...
were interested and thrilled to have the realities of war brought so vividly
before them, and if women had sometimes to shut their eyes to escape for a
moment from the tragedy of the toll of battle which the film presents, opinion
seems to be general that it was wise that the people at home should have this
glimpse of what our soldiers are doing and daring and suffering in
Picardy".[101]

###
Newspapers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Newspapers")]

Newspapers during the war were subject to the _Defence of the Realm Act_ ,
which eventually had two regulations restricting what they could publish:[102]
Regulation 18, which prohibited the leakage of sensitive military information,
troop and shipping movements; and Regulation 27, which made it an offence to
"spread false reports", "spread reports that were likely to prejudice
recruiting", "undermine public confidence in banks or currency" or cause
"disaffection to His Majesty".[102] Where the official [Press
Bureau](/w/index.php?title=Press_Bureau&action=edit&redlink=1 "Press Bureau
\(page does not exist\)") failed (it had no statutory powers until April
1916), the newspaper editors and owners operated a ruthless [self-
censorship](/wiki/Self-censorship "Self-censorship").[10] Having worked for
government, [press barons](/wiki/Press_baron "Press baron") [Viscount
Rothermere](/wiki/Harold_Harmsworth,_1st_Viscount_Rothermere "Harold
Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Rothermere"),[103] [Baron
Beaverbrook](/wiki/Max_Aitken,_1st_Baron_Beaverbrook "Max Aitken, 1st Baron
Beaverbrook") (in a sea of controversy),[104] and [Viscount
Northcliffe](/wiki/Alfred_Harmsworth,_1st_Viscount_Northcliffe "Alfred
Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Northcliffe")[105] all received titles. For these
reasons, it has been concluded that censorship, which at its height suppressed
only socialist journals (and briefly the [right wing](/wiki/Right-
wing_politics "Right-wing politics") _The Globe_) had less effect on the
British press than the reductions in advertising revenues and cost increases
which they also faced during the war.[10] One major loophole in the official
censorship lay with [parliamentary privilege](/wiki/Parliamentary_privilege
"Parliamentary privilege"), when anything said in Parliament could be reported
freely.[102] The most infamous act of censorship in the early days of the war
was the sinking of [HMS _Audacious_](/wiki/HMS_Audacious_\(1912\) "HMS
Audacious \(1912\)") in October 1914, when the press was directed not to
report on the loss, despite the sinking being observed by passengers on the
liner [RMS _Olympic_](/wiki/RMS_Olympic "RMS Olympic") and quickly reported in
the American press.[106]

The most popular papers of the period included dailies such as _[The
Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_ , _[The Daily
Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_ and _[The Morning
Post](/wiki/The_Morning_Post "The Morning Post")_ , weekly newspapers such as
_[The Graphic](/wiki/The_Graphic "The Graphic")_ and periodicals like _[John
Bull](/wiki/John_Bull_\(magazine\) "John Bull \(magazine\)")_ , which claimed
a weekly circulation of 900,000.[107] The public demand for news of the war
was reflected in the increased sales of newspapers. After the German Navy raid
on Hartlepool and Scarborough, the _[Daily Mail](/wiki/Daily_Mail "Daily
Mail")_ devoted three full pages to the raid and the _[Evening
News](/wiki/Evening_News_\(London\) "Evening News \(London\)")_ reported that
_The Times_ had sold out by a quarter past nine in the morning, even with
inflated prices.[108] The _Daily Mail_ itself increased in circulation from
800,000 a day in 1914 to 1.5 million by 1916.[10]

### News
magazines[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: News magazines")]

The public's thirst for news and information was in part satisfied by [news
magazines](/wiki/Newsmagazine "Newsmagazine"), which were dedicated to
reporting the war. They included amongst others _[The War
Illustrated](/wiki/The_War_Illustrated "The War Illustrated")_ , _[The
Illustrated War News](/wiki/The_Illustrated_War_News "The Illustrated War
News")_ , and _[The War
Pictorial](/w/index.php?title=The_War_Pictorial&action=edit&redlink=1 "The War
Pictorial \(page does not exist\)")_ , and were lavishly filled with
photographs and illustrations, regardless of their [target
audience](/wiki/Target_audience "Target audience"). Magazines were produced
for all classes, and ranged both in price and tone. Many otherwise famous
writers contributed towards these publications, of which H.G. Wells, Arthur
Conan Doyle and Rudyard Kipling were three examples. Editorial guidelines
varied; in cheaper publications especially it was considered more important to
create a sense of [patriotism](/wiki/Patriotism "Patriotism") than to relay
up-to-the-minutes news of developments of the front. Stories of German
atrocities were commonplace.[109]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Music")]

On 13 August 1914, the Irish regiment the [Connaught
Rangers](/wiki/Connaught_Rangers "Connaught Rangers") were witnessed singing
"[It's a Long Way to Tipperary](/wiki/It%27s_a_Long_Way_to_Tipperary "It's a
Long Way to Tipperary")" as they marched through [Boulogne](/wiki/Boulogne-
sur-Mer "Boulogne-sur-Mer") by the _[Daily Mail](/wiki/Daily_Mail "Daily
Mail")_ correspondent George Curnock, who reported the event in that newspaper
on 18 August 1914\. The song was then picked up by other units of the [British
Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army"). In November 1914, it was sung in a
[pantomime](/wiki/Pantomime "Pantomime") by the well-known [music
hall](/wiki/Music_hall "Music hall") singer [Florrie
Forde](/wiki/Florrie_Forde "Florrie Forde"), which helped contribute to its
worldwide popularity.[110] Another song from 1916, which became very popular
as a [music hall](/wiki/Music_hall "Music hall") and [marching
song](/wiki/Marching_song "Marching song"), boosting British morale despite
the horrors of that war, was "[Pack Up Your Troubles in Your Old Kit-
Bag](/wiki/Pack_Up_Your_Troubles_in_Your_Old_Kit-Bag "Pack Up Your Troubles in
Your Old Kit-Bag")".[111]

### War
poems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: War poems")]

Further information: [War poetry during World War I](/wiki/War_poet#WWI "War
poet")

There was also a notable group of [war poets](/wiki/War_poet "War poet") who
wrote about their own experiences of war, which caught the public attention.
Some died on active service, most famously [Rupert Brooke](/wiki/Rupert_Brooke
"Rupert Brooke"), [Isaac Rosenberg](/wiki/Isaac_Rosenberg "Isaac Rosenberg"),
and [Wilfred Owen](/wiki/Wilfred_Owen "Wilfred Owen"), while some, such as
[Siegfried Sassoon](/wiki/Siegfried_Sassoon "Siegfried Sassoon") survived.
Themes of the poems included the youth (or naivety) of the soldiers, and the
dignified manner in which they fought and died.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] This is
evident in lines such as "They fell with their faces to the foe", from the
"[Ode of Remembrance](/wiki/Ode_of_Remembrance "Ode of Remembrance")" taken
from [Laurence Binyon](/wiki/Laurence_Binyon "Laurence Binyon")'s _[For the
Fallen](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/For_the_Fallen "s:For the Fallen")_ ,
which was first published in _[The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_ in
September 1914.[112] Female poets such as [Vera Brittain](/wiki/Vera_Brittain
"Vera Brittain") also wrote from the [home front](/wiki/Home_front "Home
front"), to lament the losses of brothers and lovers fighting on the
front.[113]

##
Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Economy")]

Main article: [Economic history of World War I § British
Empire](/wiki/Economic_history_of_World_War_I#British_Empire "Economic history
of World War I")

On the whole the British successfully managed the economics of the war. There
had been no prewar plan for mobilization of economic resources. Controls were
imposed slowly, as one urgent need followed another.[114] With the City of
London the world's financial capital, it was possible to handle finances
smoothly; in all Britain spent 4 million pounds everyday on the war
effort.[115]

The economy (in terms of GDP) grew about 14% from 1914 to 1918 despite the
absence of so many men in the services; by contrast the German economy shrank
27%. The War saw a decline of civilian consumption, with a major reallocation
to munitions. The government share of GDP soared from 8% in 1913 to 38% in
1918 (compared to 50% in 1943).[116][117] The war forced Britain to use up its
financial reserves and borrow large sums from private and government creditors
in the United States.[118] Shipments of American raw materials and food
allowed Britain to feed itself and its army while maintaining his
productivity. The financing was generally successful,[119] as the City's
strong financial position minimized the damaging effects of inflation, as
opposed to much worse conditions in Germany.[120] Overall consumer consumption
declined 18% from 1914 to 1919.[121] Women were available and many entered
munitions factories and took other home front jobs vacated by men.[122][123]

Scotland specialized in providing manpower, ships, machinery, food
(particularly fish) and money. Its shipbuilding industry expanding by a
third.[124]

###
Rationing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Rationing")]

Main article: [Rationing in the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Rationing_in_the_United_Kingdom "Rationing in the United
Kingdom")

[![A document says "DEFENCE OF THE REALM", "MINISTRY OF FOOD", "BREACHES OF
THE RATIONING ORDER", "The undermentioned convictions have been recently
obtained", and a list of various offences committed and the punishments handed
out.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/%27Breaches_of_the_Rationing_Order%27_poster.jpg/220px-%27Breaches_of_the_Rationing_Order%27_poster.jpg)](/wiki/File:%27Breaches_of_the_Rationing_Order%27_poster.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%27Breaches_of_the_Rationing_Order%27_poster.jpg "Enlarge")

A British government wartime leaflet detailing the consequences of breaking
the rationing laws

In line with its "[business as usual](/wiki/Business_as_usual_\(policy\)
"Business as usual \(policy\)")" policy, the government was initially
reluctant to try to control the food markets.[125] It fought off efforts to
try to introduce minimum prices in cereal production, though relenting in the
area of controlling of essential imports (sugar, meat and grains). When it did
introduce changes, they were only limited in their effect. In 1916, it became
illegal to consume more than two courses whilst lunching in a public eating
place or more than three for dinner; fines were introduced for members of the
public found feeding the [pigeons](/wiki/Pigeon "Pigeon") or stray
animals.[63]

In January 1917, Germany started using [U-boats](/wiki/U-boats "U-boats")
(submarines) in order to sink Allied and later neutral ships bringing food to
the country in an attempt to starve Britain into surrender under their
[unrestricted submarine warfare](/wiki/Unrestricted_submarine_warfare
"Unrestricted submarine warfare") programme. One response to this threat was
to introduce voluntary [rationing](/wiki/Rationing "Rationing") in February
1917,[63] a scheme said to have been endorsed by the King and Queen
themselves.[126] Bread was subsidised from September that year; prompted by
[local authorities](/wiki/Local_government "Local government") taking matters
into their own hands, compulsory rationing was introduced in stages between
December 1917 and February 1918,[63] as Britain's supply of wheat stores
decreased to just six weeks worth.[127] It is said to have in the most part
benefited the health of the country,[63] through the 'levelling of consumption
of essential foodstuffs'.[128] To assist with rationing, [ration
books](/wiki/Rationing "Rationing") were introduced on 15 July 1918 for
butter, margarine, lard, meat, and sugar.[129] During the war, average
calorific intake decreased only three percent, but protein intake six
percent.[63]

###
Industry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Industry")]

[![Workers stand around a large forge, where a shell burns red-
hot.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/WWIworkersElisabethville.jpg/220px-
WWIworkersElisabethville.jpg)](/wiki/File:WWIworkersElisabethville.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:WWIworkersElisabethville.jpg "Enlarge")

Forging steel shell cases

Total British production fell by ten percent over the course of the war; there
were, however, increases in certain industries such as steel.[11] Although
Britain faced a highly contentious [Shell Crisis of
1915](/wiki/Shell_Crisis_of_1915 "Shell Crisis of 1915") With severe shortages
of artillery shells reported from the Western Front. In 1915, a powerful new
[Ministry of Munitions](/wiki/Ministry_of_Munitions "Ministry of Munitions")
under [David Lloyd George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David Lloyd George") was
formed to control munitions production.[130][131]

The Government's policy, according to historian and Conservative politician
[J. A. R. Marriott](/wiki/J._A._R._Marriott "J. A. R. Marriott"), was that:

    no private interest was to be permitted to obstruct the service, or imperil the safety, of the State. Trade Union regulations must be suspended; employers' profits must be limited, skilled men must fight, if not in the trenches, in the factories; man-power must be economize by the dilution of labour and the employment of women; Private factories must pass under the control of the State, and new national factories be set up. Results justified the new policy: the output was prodigious; the goods were at last delivered.[132]

By April 1915, just two million rounds of shells had been sent to France; by
the end of the war the figure had reached 187 million,[133] and a year's worth
of pre-war production of light munitions could be completed in just four days
by 1918. Aircraft production in 1914 provided employment for 60,000 men and
women; by 1918 British firms employed over 347,000.[11]

###
Labour[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Labour")]

Industrial production of munitions was a central feature of the war, and with
a third of the men in the labour force moved into the military, demand was
very high for industrial labour. Large numbers of women were employed
temporarily.[134] Most trade unions gave strong support to the war effort,
cutting back on strikes and restrictive practices. However the coal miners and
engineers were less enthusiastic.[135] Trade unions were encouraged as
membership grew from 4.1 million in 1914 to 6.5 million in 1918, peaking at
8.3 million in 1920 before relapsing to 5.4 million in 1923.[136] Membership
soared from 4.1 million in 1914 to 6.5 million in 1918, peaking at 8.3 million
in 1920 before relapsing to 5.4 million in 1923.[136] In 1914, 65% of union
members had been associated with the [Trades Union
Congress](/wiki/Trades_Union_Congress "Trades Union Congress") (TUC) rising to
77% in 1920. Women were grudgingly admitted to the trade unions. Looking at a
union of unskilled workers, Cathy Hunt concludes its regard for women workers,
"was at best inconsistent and at worst aimed almost entirely at improving and
protecting working conditions for its male members."[137] Labour's prestige
had never been higher, and it systematically placed its leaders into
Parliament.[138]

The [Munitions of War Act 1915](/wiki/Munitions_of_War_Act_1915 "Munitions of
War Act 1915") followed the [Shell Crisis of 1915](/wiki/Shell_Crisis_of_1915
"Shell Crisis of 1915") when supplies of material to the front became a
political issue. The Act forbade strikes and lockouts and replaced them with
compulsory arbitration. It set up a system of controlling war industries, and
established munitions tribunals that were special courts to enforce good
working practices. It suspended, for the duration, restrictive practices by
trade unions. It tried to control labour mobility between jobs. The courts
ruled the definition of munitions was broad enough to include textile workers
and dock workers. The 1915 act was repealed in 1919, but similar legislation
took effect during the Second World War.[139][140][141]

It was only as late as December 1917 that a War Cabinet Committee on Manpower
was established, and the British government refrained from introducing
compulsory labour direction (though 388 men were moved as part of the
voluntary National Service Scheme). Belgian refugees became workers, though
they were often seen as "job stealers". Likewise, the use of Irish workers,
because they were exempt from conscription, was another source of
resentment.[142] Worried about the impact of the dilution of labour caused by
bringing external groups into the main labour pool, workers in some areas
turned to [strike action](/wiki/Strike_action "Strike action"). The efficiency
of major industries improved markedly during the war. For example, the Singer
Clydebank sewing machine factory received over 5000 government contracts, and
made 303 million artillery shells, shell components, fuzes, and airplane
parts, as well as grenades, rifle parts, and 361,000 horseshoes. Its labour
force of 14,000 was about 70 percent female at war's end.[143]

###
Energy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Energy")]

Energy was a critical factor for the British war effort. Most of the energy
supplies came from coal mines in Britain, where the issue was labour supply.
Critical however was the flow of oil for ships, lorries and industrial use.
There were no oil wells in Britain so everything was imported. The U.S. pumped
two-thirds of the world's oil. In 1917, total British consumption was 827
million barrels, of which 85 percent was supplied by the United States, and 6
percent by Mexico.[144] The great issue in 1917 was how many tankers would
survive the German u-boats. Convoys and the construction of new tankers solved
the German threat, while tight government controls guaranteed that all
essential needs were covered. An Inter-Allied Petroleum Conference allocated
American supplies to Britain, France and Italy.[145]

Fuel oil for the Royal Navy was the highest priority. In 1917, the Royal Navy
consumed 12,500 tons a month, but had a supply of 30,000 tons a month from the
[Anglo-Persian Oil Company](/wiki/Anglo-Persian_Oil_Company "Anglo-Persian Oil
Company"), using their oil wells in Persia.[146]

## Social
change[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Social change")]

Main article: [Women's roles in the World Wars § World War
I](/wiki/Women%27s_roles_in_the_World_Wars#World_War_I "Women's roles in the
World Wars")

Variously throughout the war, serious shortage of [able-bodied](/wiki/Able-
bodied "Able-bodied") men ("manpower") occurred in the country, and women were
required to take on many of the traditional male roles, particularly in the
area of arms manufacture; though this was only significant in the later years
of the war, since unemployed men were often prioritised by employers.[12]
Women both found work in the [munitions](/wiki/Munitions "Munitions")
factories (as "munitionettes") despite initial [trade union](/wiki/Trade_union
"Trade union") opposition, which directly helped the war effort, but also in
the [Civil Service](/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Civil_Service "Her Majesty's Civil
Service"), where they took men's jobs, releasing them for the front. The
number of women employed by the service increased from 33,000 in 1911 to over
102,000 by 1921.[147] The overall increase in female employment is estimated
at 1.4 million, from 5.9 to 7.3 million,[12] and female trade union membership
increased from 357,000 in 1914 to over a million by 1918—an increase of 160
percent.[147] Beckett suggests that most of these were [working
class](/wiki/Working_class "Working class") women going into work at a younger
age than they would otherwise have done, or married women returning to
work.[12] This taken together with the fact that only 23 percent of women in
the munitions industry were actually doing men's jobs, would limit
substantially the overall impact of the war on the long-term prospects of the
working woman.[12]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Women%27s-Land-
Army-1917.jpg/220px-Women%27s-Land-Army-1917.jpg)](/wiki/File:Women%27s-Land-
Army-1917.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Women%27s-Land-Army-1917.jpg "Enlarge")

First World War poster

When the government targeted women early in the war focussed on extending
their existing roles – helping with Belgian refugees, for example—but also on
improving recruitment rates amongst men. They did this both through the so-
called "Order of the White Feather" and through the promise of home comforts
for the men while they were at the front. In February 1916, groups were set up
and a campaign started to get women to help in agriculture and in March 1917,
the [Women's Land Army](/wiki/Women%27s_Land_Army "Women's Land Army") was set
up. One goal was to attract middle-class women who would act as models for
patriotic engagement in nontraditional duties. However the uniform of the
Women's Land Army included male overalls and trousers, which sparked debate on
the propriety of such cross-dressing. The government responded with rhetoric
that explicitly feminized the new roles.[148] In 1918, the [Board of
Trade](/wiki/Board_of_Trade "Board of Trade") estimated that there were
148,000 women in agricultural employment, though a figure of nearly 260,000
has also been suggested.[12]

The war also caused a split in the [British suffragette
movement](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_Kingdom "Women's suffrage in
the United Kingdom"), with the mainstream, represented by [Emmeline
Pankhurst](/wiki/Emmeline_Pankhurst "Emmeline Pankhurst") and her daughter
[Christabel](/wiki/Christabel_Pankhurst "Christabel Pankhurst")'s [Women's
Social and Political Union](/wiki/Women%27s_Social_and_Political_Union
"Women's Social and Political Union"), calling a '[ceasefire](/wiki/Ceasefire
"Ceasefire")' in their campaign for the duration of the war. In contrast, more
