[radical](/wiki/Extremism "Extremism") suffragettes, like the [Women's
Suffrage Federation](/wiki/Women%27s_Suffrage_Federation "Women's Suffrage
Federation") run by Emmeline's other daughter, [Sylvia](/wiki/Sylvia_Pankhurst
"Sylvia Pankhurst"), continued their (at times violent) struggle. Women were
also allowed to join the armed forces in a non-combatant role[12] and by the
end of the War 80,000 women had joined the armed forces in auxiliary roles
such as nursing and cooking.[149]

Following the war, millions of returning soldiers were still not entitled to
vote.[150] This posed another dilemma for politicians since they could be seen
to be withholding the vote from the very men who had just fought to preserve
the British democratic political system. The [Representation of the People Act
1918](/wiki/Representation_of_the_People_Act_1918 "Representation of the
People Act 1918") attempted to solve the problem, enfranchising all adult
males as long as they were over 21 years old and were resident
householders.[150] It also gave the vote to women over 30 who met minimum
property qualifications. The enfranchisement of this latter group was accepted
as recognition of the contribution made by women defence workers,[150] though
the actual feelings of [members of
parliament](/wiki/Members_of_parliament#United_Kingdom "Members of
parliament") (MPs) at the time is questioned.[12] In the same year the
[Parliament (Qualification of Women) Act
1918](/wiki/Parliament_\(Qualification_of_Women\)_Act_1918 "Parliament
\(Qualification of Women\) Act 1918") allowed women over 21 to stand as
MPs.[151]

The new coalition government of 1918 charged itself with the task of creating
a "land fit for heroes", from a speech given in
[Wolverhampton](/wiki/Wolverhampton "Wolverhampton") by David Lloyd George on
23 November 1918, where he stated "What is our task? To make Britain a fit
country for heroes to live in."[152] More generally, the war has been
credited, both during and after the conflict, with removing some of the social
barriers that had pervaded Victorian and Edwardian Britain.[6]

## Regional
conditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Regional conditions")]

The War had a profound influence upon rural areas, as the U-boat blockade
required the government to take full control of the food chain, as well as
agricultural labour. Cereal production was a high priority, and the [Corn
Production Act 1917](/wiki/Corn_Production_Act_1917 "Corn Production Act
1917") guaranteed prices, regulated wage rates, and required farmers to meet
efficiency standards. The government campaigned heavily for turning marginal
land into cropland.[153][154][155] The [Women's Land
Army](/wiki/Women%27s_Land_Army "Women's Land Army") brought in 23,000 young
women from the towns and cities to milk cows, pick fruit and otherwise replace
the men who joined the services.[156] More extensive use of tractors and
machinery also replaced farm labourers. However, there was a shortage of both
men and horses on the land by late 1915. County [War Agricultural Executive
Committees](/wiki/War_Agricultural_Executive_Committee "War Agricultural
Executive Committee") reported that the continued removal of men was
undercutting food production because of the farmers' belief that operating a
farm required a set number of men and horses.[157]

[Kenneth Morgan](/wiki/Kenneth_O._Morgan "Kenneth O. Morgan") argues that,
"the overwhelming mass of the Welsh people cast aside their political and
industrial divisions and threw themselves into the war with gusto."
Intellectuals and ministers actively promoted the war spirit. With 280,000 men
enrolled in the services (14% of the population), the proportionate effort in
Wales outstripped both England and Scotland.[158] However Adrian Gregory
points out that the Welsh coal miners, while officially supporting the war
effort, refused the government request to cut short their vacation time. After
some debate, the miners agreed to extend the working day.[159]

Scotland's distinctive characteristics have attracted significant attention
from scholars.[160] Daniel Coetzee shows it supported the war effort with
widespread enthusiasm.[161]

##
Casualties[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Casualties")]

See also: [World War I casualties](/wiki/World_War_I_casualties "World War I
casualties")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f4/National_Fund_for_Welsh_Troops2.jpg/220px-
National_Fund_for_Welsh_Troops2.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Fund_for_Welsh_Troops2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:National_Fund_for_Welsh_Troops2.jpg "Enlarge")

Poster for a fundraising event in support of Welsh troops by [Frank
Brangwyn](/wiki/Frank_Brangwyn "Frank Brangwyn")

In the post war publication _Statistics of the Military Effort of the British
Empire During the Great War 1914–1920_ ([The War Office](/wiki/War_Office "War
Office"), March 1922), the official report lists 908,371 'soldiers' as being
either [killed in action](/wiki/Killed_in_action "Killed in action"), dying of
wounds, dying as [prisoners of war](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war")
or missing in action in the World War. (This is broken down into Britain and
its colonies 704,121; British India 64,449; Canada 56,639; Australia 59,330;
New Zealand 16,711; South Africa 7,121.)[15] Listed separately were the Royal
Navy (including the Royal Naval Air Service until 31 March 1918) war dead and
missing of 32,287 and the [Merchant Navy](/wiki/Merchant_Navy "Merchant Navy")
war dead of 14,661.[15] The figures for the Royal Flying Corps and the nascent
Royal Air Force were not given in the War Office report.[15]

A second publication, _Casualties and Medical Statistics_ (1931), the final
volume of the _Official Medical History of the War_ , gives British Empire
Army losses by cause of death.[16] The total losses in combat from 1914 to
1918 were 876,084, which included 418,361 killed, 167,172 died of wounds,
113,173 died of disease or injury, 161,046 missing presumed dead and 16,332
died as a prisoner of war.[16]

The [Commonwealth War Graves
Commission](/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission "Commonwealth War Graves
Commission") lists 888,246 war dead from the UK and colonies (excluding the
[dominions](/wiki/Dominion "Dominion"), which are listed separately). This
figure includes identified burials and those commemorated by name on
memorials; there are an additional 187,644 unidentified burials from the
Commonwealth (then Empire) as a whole.[162]

The civilian death rate exceeded the prewar level by 292,000, which included
109,000 deaths due to food shortages and 183,577 from [Spanish
Flu](/wiki/Spanish_Flu "Spanish Flu").[15] The 1922 War Office report detailed
the deaths of 1,260 civilians and 310 military personnel due to air and sea
bombardment the home islands.[163] Losses at sea were 908 civilians and 63
fisherman killed by [U-boat](/wiki/U-boat "U-boat") attacks.[164]

With a population of 4.8 million in 1911, Scotland sent 690,000 men to the
war, of whom 74,000 died in combat or from disease, and 150,000 were seriously
wounded.[165][166] At times Scottish troops made up large proportions of the
active combatants, and suffered corresponding loses, as at the [Battle of
Loos](/wiki/Battle_of_Loos "Battle of Loos"), where there were three full
Scots divisions and other Scottish units.[79] Thus, although Scots were only
10 per cent of the British population, they made up 15 per cent of the
national armed forces and eventually accounted for 20 per cent of the
dead.[167] Some areas, like the thinly populated Island of [Lewis and
Harris](/wiki/Lewis_and_Harris "Lewis and Harris") suffered some of the
highest proportional losses of any part of Britain.[79] Clydeside shipyards
and the engineering shops of west-central Scotland became the most significant
centre of shipbuilding and arms production in the Empire. In the Lowlands,
particularly Glasgow, poor working and living conditions led to industrial and
political unrest.[167]

## Legacy and
memory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_the_First_World_War&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Legacy and memory")]

[![A map showing various areas highlighted, including Great Britain, Canada,
South Africa, Australia and New
Zealand](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/British_Empire_in_1898.png/300px-
British_Empire_in_1898.png)](/wiki/File:British_Empire_in_1898.png)

The extent of the British Empire in 1898

[![The same map, with additional areas coloured \(see
text\)](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/British_Empire_in_1914.png/300px-
British_Empire_in_1914.png)](/wiki/File:British_Empire_in_1914.png)

The extent of the British Empire in 1914

[![The same map, with additional areas coloured \(see
text\)](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/British_Empire_1921.png/300px-
British_Empire_1921.png)](/wiki/File:British_Empire_1921.png)

The extent of the British Empire in 1921

The horrors of the Western Front as well as Gallipoli and Mesopotamia were
seared into the collective consciousness of the twentieth century. To a large
extent the understanding of the war in popular culture focused on the first
day of the Battle of the Somme. Historian [A. J. P.
Taylor](/wiki/A._J._P._Taylor "A. J. P. Taylor") argued, "The Somme set the
picture by which future generations saw the First World War: brave helpless
soldiers; blundering obstinate generals; nothing achieved."[168]

Images of trench warfare became iconic symbols of human suffering and
endurance. The post-war world had many veterans who were maimed or damaged by
shell shock. In 1921 1,187,450 men were in receipt of pensions for war
disabilities, with a fifth of these having suffered serious loss of limbs or
eyesight, paralysis or lunacy.[169]

The war was a major economic catastrophe as Britain went from being the
world's largest overseas investor to being its biggest debtor, with interest
payments consuming around 40 percent of the national budget.[170] Inflation
more than doubled between 1914 and its peak in 1920, while the value of the
Pound Sterling fell by 61.2 percent. Reparations in the form of free German
coal depressed the local industry, precipitating the [1926 General
Strike](/wiki/UK_General_Strike_1926 "UK General Strike 1926").[170] During
the war British private investments abroad were sold, raising £550 million.
However, £250 million new investment also took place during the war. The net
financial loss was therefore approximately £300 million; less than two years
investment compared to the pre-war average rate and more than replaced by
1928.[171] Material loss was "slight": the most significant being 40 percent
of the British merchant fleet sunk by German U-boats. Most of this was
replaced in 1918 and all immediately after the war.[172] The military
historian [Correlli Barnett](/wiki/Correlli_Barnett "Correlli Barnett") has
argued that "in objective truth the Great War in no way inflicted crippling
economic damage on Britain" but that the war only "crippled the British
_psychologically_ " (emphasis in original).[173]

Less concrete changes include the growing assertiveness of the
[Dominions](/wiki/British_Dominions "British Dominions") within the British
Empire. Battles such as [Gallipoli](/wiki/Battle_of_Gallipoli "Battle of
Gallipoli") for Australia and New Zealand,[174] and [Vimy
Ridge](/wiki/Battle_of_Vimy_Ridge "Battle of Vimy Ridge") for Canada led to
increased national pride and a greater reluctance to remain subordinate to
London.[18] These battles were often portrayed favourably in these nations'
propaganda as symbolic of their power during the war.[18][174] The war
released pent-up indigenous [nationalism](/wiki/Nationalism "Nationalism"), as
populations tried to take advantage of the precedent set by the introduction
of [self-determination](/wiki/Self-determination "Self-determination") in
eastern Europe. Britain was to face unrest in Ireland (1919–21), India (1919),
Egypt (1919–23), Palestine (1920–21) and Iraq (1920) at a time when they were
supposed to be demilitarising.[17] Nevertheless, Britain's only territorial
loss came in Ireland,[17] where the delay in finding a resolution to the [home
rule](/wiki/Home_rule "Home rule") issue, along with the 1916 [Easter
Rising](/wiki/Easter_Rising "Easter Rising") and a failed attempt to introduce
[conscription in Ireland](/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1918 "Conscription
Crisis of 1918"), increased support for separatist radicals, and led
indirectly to the outbreak of the [Irish War of
Independence](/wiki/Irish_War_of_Independence "Irish War of Independence") in
1919.[175]

Further change came in 1919. With the [Treaty of
Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles"), London took
charge of an additional 1,800,000 square miles (4,700,000 km2) and 13 million
new subjects.[176] The colonies of Germany and the [Ottoman
Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") were distributed to the Allied
powers (and to Australia, New Zealand and South Africa) as [League of Nations
mandates](/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate "League of Nations mandate"), with
the United Kingdom at least gaining control of [Palestine and
Transjordan](/wiki/British_Mandate_of_Palestine "British Mandate of
Palestine"), [Iraq](/wiki/British_Mandate_of_Mesopotamia "British Mandate of
Mesopotamia"), parts of [Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroons "Cameroons") and
[Togo](/wiki/Togo "Togo"), and [Tanganyika](/wiki/Tanganyika
"Tanganyika").[177] Indeed, the British Empire reached its territorial peak
after the settlement.[17]
